section: Accuray will defend or settle any action brought against Distributor and shall indemnify and hold Distributor harmless from any liability, damages and expenses (including court costs and reasonable attorneys' fees) to the extent that it is based upon a third-party claim that a Product, as provided by Accuray to Distributor under this Agreement, infringes any patent issued in the United States, Germany, or in the country in which the Customer requested delivery of the Product or any copyright or misappropriates any trade secret, and will pay any costs and damages made in settlement or awarded against Distributor in final decision resulting from any such claim, provided that Distributor: (i) gives Accuray prompt notice of any such claim; (ii) gives Accuray sole control of the defense and any related settlement of any such claim; and (iii) gives Accuray, at Accuray's expense, all reasonable information, assistance and authority in connection with the foregoing.
explanation: This section seems to put the onus of legal defense on Accuray for patent, copyright, or trade secret infringements, but it limits this responsibility to claims based on patents issued only in specific locations (US, Germany, or the customer's country). This creates a potential loophole: If a claim arises from a patent issued in a different country (e.g., France), Accuray's obligation to defend and indemnify might not be triggered, leaving the distributor vulnerable.

section: 4.1.2. Shipment. All shipments shall be made F.C.A. Port of Oakland, California, USA. Transfer of risk from Accuray to Distributor shall occur at such F.C.A. location as provided in F.C.A. terms and transfer of title shall occur at the same time. Distributor may request Accuray to use a particular freight carrier, and Accuray agrees to do so, if feasible. If not feasible in Accuray's reasonable judgment, then Accuray shall promptly advise Distributor of the reasons. If no such request is made, Accuray shall ship in accordance with any instructions contained in the Purchase Order or via FedEx ground, with no extra insurance. Accuray shall bill any actual freight costs to Distributor. Any supplementary shipping costs arising from the need to meet the delivery deadline set forth in the Purchase Order by way of expedited delivery shall be borne by Accuray, if such delivery deadline was at least six months after the submission of such Purchase Order by Distributor. For example, if a Purchase Order was submitted on June 1, with a requested delivery date of December 1, any expedited delivery expenses required in order to ensure delivery by December 1 shall be borne by Accuray, while if the requested delivery date was October 1, any expedited delivery expenses required in order to ensure delivery by October 1 shall be borne by Distributor.
explanation: This section outlines who pays for expedited shipping based on the requested delivery date in the purchase order. It says Accuray pays if the delivery deadline is at least six months after the PO submission. However, the second half of the sentence contradicts the first half, since it is not clear on who bears the cost of delivery. This causes ambiguity.

section: Accuray shall bear the cost of any bank charges assessed by its bank for a letter of credit and any commission charge for a wire transfer. Past due balances on any reasonably undisputed amount shall bear interest at the rate of 1.0% per month or, if lower, the maximum amount permitted by applicable law. If Distributor is a "business person" (as defined in  14 of the German Civil Code, "BGB"), the payment shall be deemed past due only if Distributor fails to pay in response to a payment demand note received after payment becomes due.
explanation: This section dicates the past due amount for wire transfers or letter of credits. There is ambiguity in legal terms, since the German Civil Code applies to only the distributor and not to Accuray, if the distributor is a business person. This makes this section unenforcable under national law.
